description: From Middle English profit, from Old French profit (Modern French profit), from Latin prōfectus (“advance, progress, growth, increase, profit”), from proficiō (“to go forward, advance, make progress, be profitable or useful”). Doublet of profect.

entries.meaning: (accounting, economics) Total income or cash flow minus expenditures. The money or other benefit a non-governmental organization or individual receives in exchange for products and services sold at an advertised price.
examples: Let no man anticipate uncertain profits.
Reading such an enlightening book on the subject was of much profit to his studies.

entries.meaning: (property law) Ellipsis of profit à prendre.

verbs.description: profit (third-person singular simple present profits, present participle profiting, simple past and past participle profited)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To benefit (somebody), be of use to (somebody).
examples: The word preached did not profit them.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, construed with from) To benefit, gain.
(intransitive, construed with from) To take advantage of, exploit, use.
